chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    Seven<break time="500ms"/>   <s>To Polycarp, the chief priest.</s>
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>

I can't speak for the Greeks or others, but I believe it's enough for good people to truly understand and express the truth within themselves. Anything aligned with the law of truth, when presented rightly and purely, will refute anything else that pretends to be true. It's unnecessary, then, to argue about who reveals the truth to whom. Everyone claims to have a royal coin, but they only possess a deceptive shadow of something pure. If you challenge one, another will argue over the same thing.

But when the true thing is rightly placed, and everything else is dismissed with laughter, anything that doesn't hold consistently is expelled from the realm of true truth by itself. Knowing this, I didn't rush to speak to the Greeks or others. I wanted to first understand the truth, and then, as I should, speak it.

When you ask why I criticize the sophist Apollophanes, as if using the Greeks' ways against them, it would be more accurate to say that the Greeks use what is divine in non-holy ways, trying to replace divine worship with human wisdom. Therefore, I say there is much glory in some poets who remain materially and emotionally, serving creation rather than the Creator. But Apollophanes himself does not use what is divine in holy ways.

The knowledge of what exists, rightly spoken by his philosophy and called the wisdom of God by the divine Paul, needed to bring true philosophers back to the cause of their existence and knowledge.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
To avoid challenging others' opinions or even its own beyond reason, we must consider Apollophanes, a wise man. He sometimes transcended heavenly order and motion, unless there was a guiding force, creating and transforming everything according to the sacred word. So, how does he not worship what is unknown to us, drawing from the truly existing God, guided by an ineffable power? The sun and the moon are defined by Him in their supernatural state, remaining completely still in the universe, with everything aligned according to the measure of the whole day.

Furthermore, if all that is superior and contained is elevated, do the contained things not revolve around them? And when a day almost triples in duration and spans 20 hours, it doesn't always reverse and go back by opposite paths. Thus, in very supernatural contrary revolutions, the sun, in its course, wraps its fivefold motion in 10 hours, then analytically retraces a new path in the other 10 hours.

This rightly impressed the Babylonians and conquered Hezekiah without a fight, as if equal to a certain God and surpassing men. And here, I do not speak of the great operations in Egypt or other divine signs made elsewhere, but of the common and celestial, triumphing in the universe and in all things.

However, Apollophanes says these things are not true. Instead, they are attributed to the priestly memories of the Persians, and the Magi still complete the memorable triple myth of Mithras. But let it be allowed for him due to ignorance or great disbelief. Tell him: What do you say about the eclipse made on the saving cross?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: As we both arrived near the city of the sun, we were amazed to see the moon crossing in front of the sun—outside the usual time of conjunction—and then, from 9 AM until evening, it unbelievably stood opposite the sun's diameter. Let me point out something else. We observed the setting beginning from the east, reaching the solar summit, and then moving backward, not from the same place, with both the setting and clearing occurring contrary to the diameter. These were the supernatural events of that time, all orchestrated by Christ alone, with His immense power, beyond count. If you think it's appropriate, tell Apollophanes, and he will correct me, as I was there with you, observing, seeking everything, and sharing. During that time, divination was neglected, and I don't know why. Then Apollophanes left and said to me as events unfolded: "These, dear Dionysius, are the divine changes of events." That's what we mentioned in the letter. But you have the ability to complete what's missing and bring forth a man wise in God, who exists greatly, and who is truly willing to learn the supreme truth of our religion.
